qas.question: What is the most common source of new genes in eukaryotic lineages?
What creates copy number variation of an existing gene in the genome?
What are the genes that result from eukaryotic gene duplication called?
What type of copy can gene duplication sometimes result in?
What are functional copies of a gene which have a loss of function due to mutation called?

context: The most common source of new genes in eukaryotic lineages is <a0_0><a1_0>gene duplication<a1_0/><a0_0/>, which creates copy number variation of an existing gene in the genome. The resulting genes (<a2_0>paralogs<a2_0/>) may then diverge in sequence and in function. Sets of genes formed in this way comprise a gene family. Gene duplications and losses within a family are common and represent a major source of evolutionary biodiversity. Sometimes, gene duplication may result in a <a3_0>nonfunctional<a3_0/> copy of a gene, or a functional copy may be subject to mutations that result in loss of function; such nonfunctional genes are called <a4_0>pseudogenes<a4_0/>.:7.6
